College of Materials Science and Engineering Qiqihar University Qiqihar 161006 China Enlarging reaction temperature and raising the resistance of SO2 and H2O for NH3-SCR is still a challenge. Meanwhile, the role of Fe and Cu over the supported TNU-9 catalysts is not so clear either for NH3-SCR reaction. Aiming at the above-mentioned problems, Fe and Cu bimetallic co-doped TNU-9 catalysts were prepared by solution ion-exchanged method and the effect of the exchanged order of Fe and Cu on NH3-SCR activity was conducted. What's more, the resistance of SO2/H2O and DFT calculations are also investigated. As a comparison, the activity Fe/T9 and Cu/T9 were examined. The reason that the different activity of Fe and Cu was also explained through DFT calculations. The glorious catalyst, Cu-2Fe/T9 synthesized via exchanging Cu first for twice and then Fe for once, demonstrated outstanding catalytic performance with the NOx conversion ca. 100 % at 225–450 °C and exceeding 80 % in the temperature range of 200–500 °C. It was attributed to minimizing the oxidation of Fe2+. And the most amazing thing was that Cu-2Fe/T9 had better the resistance of SO2 and worse the resistance of H2O than Cu/T9 at 225 °C. It was because that SO2 was more easily adsorbed at the Fe site, resulting in Fe protecting the active site Cu and the sulfation also provided more strong acidic sites, which were confirmed by DFT calculations and NH3-TPD. In addition, monomeric iron was more susceptible to water and the migration of ion-exchanged iron aggregated to form metal oxide clusters. Graphical abstract Fe and Cu bimetallic modified TNU-9 catalysts were prepared by solution ion-exchanged method. The glorious catalyst, Cu-2Fe/T9 synthesized via exchanging Cu first for twice and then Fe for once, demonstrates outstanding catalytic performance due to minimizing the oxidation of Fe2+. Interestingly, Cu-2Fe/T9 has better the resistance of SO2 due to Fe protecting the active site Cu and the sulfation providing more strong acidic sites. Image, graphical abstract Keywords TNU-9 NH3-SCR Cu Fe Exchange order Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the past few decades, nitrogen oxides (NOx=NO2+NO) are the main pollutants in automobile and industrial exhaust, causing acid rain, smog and endangering human health [1,2]. The regulations of NOx emission standards in various countries are becoming more and more stringent. Therefore, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) is one of the most effective and commonly used methods to reduce NOx [3]. SCR refers to the reduction of NOx to N2 and H2O in the presence of O2. One of the most commonly used reducing agents is NH3. The key of NH3-SCR reaction is the catalyst due to it reducing the activation energy and increasing the reaction rate [4]. Among such a wide family of catalysts, zeolites seem to be particularly interesting due to its advantages such as large specific surface area, high hydrothermal stability and strong acid and have been extensively studied [5]. At present, ZSM-5 zeolite is widely used as the support [6], but its poor water resistance also limits its application. TNU-9 molecular sieve is a new three-dimensional ten-ring cross-structure microporous molecular sieve prepared by Hong et al. [7]. Its structure is similar to ZSM-5. They found that TNU-9 had good hydrothermal stability and strong surface acidity. Liu et al. [8] also found that Mo/TNU-9 had better stability than Mo/ZSM-5, which might be because Mo/TNU-9 had unique three-dimensional 10-member-ring channel structure with the presence of large 12-member-ring cavities. In addition, Franch-Marti et al.[9] also found that the catalytic activity of TNU-9 in the presence of water was basically unchanged, and it had better water resistance compared with β molecular sieve, IM-5, and ZSM-5. Copper based molecular sieve catalysts have outstanding catalytic activity at low temperature [10,11], and iron based catalysts have poor performance at the low reaction temperature [12,13]. At present, it is generally believed that the reason for this difference may be the inhibition of NH3. In order to further study the inhibition effect of NH3, kinetic model studies have been widely discussed. Sjovall et al. [14] studied the inhibition of ammonia on Cu-ZSM-5 at low temperature in combination with flow reactor experiments and kinetic modeling. When the concentration of NH3 in wet feed increased from 200 to 800 ppm at 175 °C, there was almost no inhibition of NH3 when NH3/NO≤1, resulting in enhanced NO conversion. Kröcher et al. [15] found that the inhibition effect of Fe-ZSM-5 was more obvious, and excessive NH3 content hindered the improvement of denitrification activity at low temperature (<350 °C). However, the inhibition degree of NH3 decreased with the increase of temperature, and finally disappeared at 400 °C. As for the cause of NH3 inhibition, there are two viewpoints in the academic circle. First, the inhibition is due to the competitive adsorption of ammonia and NO at the active Fe site [16]. Another possible explanation is based on the redox mechanism. Devadas et al. [17] believed that the inhibitory effect was due to the fact that Fe3+ was easily reduced to Fe2+ in excess NH3 below 300 °C, which reduced the active Fe3+ and led to a decline in catalytic activity. With the increase of reaction temperature, the inhibition of NH3 on Fe-based catalyst disappeared, and the oxidation of NH3 on Cu-based catalyst resulted in the decrease of catalytic activity [18], which resulted in the poor high-temperature activity of Cu-based catalyst and good high-temperature activity of iron-based catalyst. It was found that the combination of Fe and Cu could make up for the lack of a single metal catalyst. Doan et al. [19] prepared Cu-Fe modified ZSM-5 zeolite and found that bimetal-supported catalysts effectively broadened the temperature window, hydrothermal stability and sulfur resistance of the denitrification reaction. Amazingly, Jouini et al. [20] prepared a series of catalysts using the solid ion-exchange method. They found that the ion-exchange order of iron and copper had an important effect on the dispersion and coordination environment of the resulting metal species, which might lead to different activities. However, the study has pointed out that the catalyst prepared by solid ion-exchange method had a high metal content. It led to the agglomeration of a large number of oxide. However, the catalyst prepared by water ion-exchange method had a high dispersion of metal and no significant decrease in activity [21]. To our knowledge, no researchers have investigated the effects of the loading order of Fe and Cu on the NH3-SCR activity of the supported TNU-9 catalyst using the solution ion-exchanged method. Therefore, TNU-9 was used as the support to improve hydrophobicity, and Cu and Fe active components were used to broaden the temperature window. We were aim to obtain a catalyst with wide temperature operating window and good hydrophobicity. The influence of metal exchange order in solution ion-exchanged method on the physicochemical properties and NH3-SCR properties of the catalyst was explored. In order to study deeply the catalytic mechanism, the activities of Cu/T9 and Fe/T9 and DFT were investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 The preparation of catalysts The synthesis route of the catalyst is displayed in Scheme 1 and the specific steps are as follows. Molecular sieve TNU-9 (SiO2/Al2O3=60) was synthesized by dynamic hydrothermal crystallization method [7]. The template agent 1, 4-MPP was synthesized by refluxing of N-Methylpyrrolidine and 1,4-Dibromo butane in acetone. 1, 4-MPP was dissolved in water, and then Al(NO3)3·9H2O and NaOH were added. At last, silica black was slowly added in the process of rapid stirring and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. The gel was then dynamically crystallized at 160 °C for 10 d, resulting in a molar ratio of 30 SiO2: 11 Na2O: 0.5 Al2O3:4.5 (1, 4-MPP): 1200 H2O. The Na-TNU-9 (Na-T9) was acquired by filtering, washing in deionized water, drying, and calcination at 550 °C for 6 h. Then, 1.0 g Na-T9 was ion-exchanged with 0.5 mol/L NH4NO3 solution at 90 °C for 5 h. The above mixture was filtered, rinsed with deionized water and dried. The ion-exchange was repeated twice. The obtained solid was calcined at 500 °C for 4 h, which was labeled as H-TNU-9 (H-T9). 1.0 g H-T9 was added to 3.56 × 10−3 mol/L FeSO4·7H2O aqueous solution under N2 atmosphere and then the pH of the solution was adjusted to 3 with 0.1 mol/L HNO3 solution [22]. The mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 24 h under N2 atmosphere and then filtered, dried, calcined at 500 °C for 4 h, which was tagged as Fe/TNU-9 (Fe/T9). To obtain xFe-Cu/TNU-9 (xFe-Cu/T9) (x was the mass percentage of Fe to the support H-T9), the preparation of xFe/TNU-9 (xFe/T9) was similar with above method and the quantity addition of FeSO4·7H2O was different. 1.0 g the prepared xFe/T9 was ion-exchanged with 3.12 × 10−3 mol/L CuSO4·5H2O solution at 80 °C for 24 h and the mixture was filtered, rinsed with deionized water and dried. The above-mentioned process was repeated twice and then the solid was calcined at 500 °C for 4 h to gain xFe-Cu/T9. 1.0 g H-T9 was ion-exchanged with 3.12 × 10−3 mol/L CuSO4·5H2O solution at 80 °C for 24 h and the mixture was filtered, rinsed with deionized water and dried. The above-mentioned process was repeated twice. The resulting solid Cu/TNU-9 (Cu/T9) was achieved was calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. Cu-2Fe/TNU-9 (Cu-2Fe/T9) was prepared by ion-exchange method. Under N2 atmosphere, 1.0 g Cu/T9 was dispersed in deionized water, then a certain amount of FeSO4·7H2O was added, and the pH of the solution was adjusted to 3 with 1 mol/L HNO3 solution. The mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 24 h under N2 atmosphere, and then filtered, dried, calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. For comparison, Cu2Fe/TNU-9 (Cu2Fe/T9) was prepared and the preparation of Cu2Fe/T9 was analogous to Fe/T9 and the difference was 3.56 × 10−3 mol/L FeSO4·7H2O aqueous solution and 3.12 × 10−3 mol/L CuSO4·5H2O solution were added simultaneously. 2.2 Characterizations The XRD patterns of the catalysts were performed by a Smartlab X-ray Diffractometer. SEM images and EDS were measured by TESCAN MIRA LMS + Quantax 200 XFlash 660. XPS spectra were recored using ESCA-LAB250XI. Both H2-TPR experiment and NH3-TPD of all catalysts were implemented by AutoChem 2720 instrument. FT-IR analysis were performed by Spectrum One B type infrared spectrometer equipment. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurement SCR catalytic performances were carried out on the fixed bed reactor. 0.3 g catalyst of 40–60 mesh was placed in the quartz tube (internal diameter of 8 mm). After that, the gas mixture including 500 ppm NO, 500 ppm NH3, 5 % O2, 100 ppm SO2, 10 % H2O and N2 (the balance gas) was introduced. The flow rate of gas is 100 mL/min. The gas concentrations including inlet and outlet was measured by gas detector, respectively. The NOx conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated by Eqs. (1) and (2) and based on the inlet and outlet gas concentrations (1) Conversio n N O x = [ N O x ] i n l e t − [ N O x ] o u t l e t [ N O x ] i n l e t (2) Selectivit y N 2 = 1 − 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t l e t [ N H 3 ] i n l e t + [ N O x ] i n l e t − [ N H 3 ] o u t l e t − [ N O x ] o u t l e t Where inlet stands for the concentration of the gas at the inlet while oulet stands for outlet concentration. 2.4 Computational methods Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations were used to obtain adsorption energies of NO, NH3, SO2 and H2O on Cu/T9 and Fe/T9. The exchange correlation functional is approximated by the generalized gradient GGA [23]. Adsorption energy is calculated according to Eq. (3): (3) E a d s = E t o t − E m o l − E s l a b Where Etot is the total energy of the system containing adsorbent, Emol is the energy of adsorbent, and Eslab is the total energy of the adsorption substrate. Adsorption energy (Eads) greater than 0 is endothermic, adsorption energy less than 0 is exothermic. Heat release is more stable than heat absorption. The greater the heat release and the smaller the heat absorption, the easier the adsorption is [24]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR activity and H2O/SO2 resistance The catalytic performance of the different catalysts is displayed in Fig. 1 . It is evident from the Fig. 1a that Cu/T9 has good low temperature activity and NOx conversion is ca. 100 % at 200–350 °C. Nevertheless, the denitrification activity of Cu/T9 decreases sharply when the temperature exceeds 350 °C, which is due to the occurrence of ammonia peroxidation [18]. Fe/T9 displays good high temperature activity, whereas low temperature NH3-SCR performance is very poor [25]. The literature reported that the competitive adsorption of ammonia and NO at the active Fe site gave rise to the decrease of NH3-SCR activity [16]. According to the DFT results (Table 1 ), the adsorption of NH3 is much better than that of NO, and there is no competitive adsorption. Therefore, the reason for the decrease in activity may be the conversion of Fe3+ to Fe2+ in excess NH3 below 300 °C. Devadas et al. [17] believed that Fe3+ was easily reduced to Fe2+ in excess NH3 below 300 °C, thus resulting in a decrease in SCR activity. Fe is introduced to Cu/T9 for the sake of expanding reaction temperature window due to the synergistic effect of Cu and Fe. Furthermore, the NH3-SCR implications of Fe content is also examined. It is also noticeable that the low temperature activity gradually decreases and the high temperature activity gradually increases with the augmenting of Fe content. Taking into account the range of temperature window, we may safely come to the conclusion that the perfect loading of Fe is 2 % and 2Fe-Cu/T9 reveals the better outstanding catalytic performance than 1Fe-Cu/T9 and 3Fe-Cu/T9. The effect of the order of ion-exchange on catalytic activity is also investigated. As is obvious from catalytic results, Cu-2Fe/T9 demonstrates the more glorious catalytic performance than 2Fe-Cu/T9 and Cu2Fe/T9 at 200–450 °C. The NOx conversion of Cu-2Fe/T9 is more than 80 % at 200–500 °C, especially approaching 100 % NOx conversion in the temperature range of 225–450 °C. The implication of these results is that the optimal sequence of exchange is Cu and then Fe due to minimizing the oxidation of Fe2+. The study found that Cu ion-exchange in the first step could improve catalytic performance because of well-dispersed Fe-Cu nanocomposites and a large amounts of isolated species. However, Fe ion-exchange in the first step could reduce activity, which was because that Fe2O3 nanoparticles occupied the external surface of Cu-Fe-ZSM-5 and CuO nanoparticles were formed [20]. In addition, N2 selectivity of all catalysts are ca. 100 % (Fig. 1b). In order to illustrate catalytic performance of Cu-2Fe/T9, the NO oxidation experiment is performed (Fig. 1c). It can be seen that Fe/T9 has stronger NO oxidation performance than Cu/T9, and the oxidation of NO→NO2 can promote the occurrence of "fast SCR" [26]. "Fast SCR" reaction can greatly improve the SCR activity above 200 °C [27,28]. Fig. 1d shows the NOx conversion of Fe/T9 and Cu/T9 in the presence of SO2 at 175–500 °C. It can be clearly seen that when SO2 is introduced, Fe/T9 has better sulfur resistance and Cu/T9 is more affected by SO2 because of Cu active sites poisoned in the low temperature region. However, the NOx conversion of Fe/T9 and Cu/T9 both increase in the high temperature region, which is because that the sulfation also offers more strong acidic sites on the basis of the results of NH3-TPD and strong acid sites could restrain the oxidation of NH3 (Fig. 2 ). The literature found that the change of SCR performance was different in the presence of different concentration of SO2 in connection with the different generating rate of SO4 2− species [29]. Zhang et al. [30] found that the sulfation also provided more strong acidic sites, which was in favour of the high-temperature SCR performance. Yu et al. [31] proposed that strong acid sites could inhibit NH3 oxidation at high temperatures. The influence of SO2 and H2O on the activity at 225 °C is studied (Fig. 1e). When SO2 is introduced after 2 h, the activity of Cu/T9 decreases slightly due to the sulfation of active site copper. Its activity remains unchanged when the reaction is going on for 2 h in the presence of SO2. However, the catalytic performance of Cu-2Fe/T9 makes no change in the presence of SO2 for 6 h and it exhibits better SCR activity than Cu/T9 in the presence of SO2, it could be because that the addition of Fe protects the active site Cu [32]. In addition, according to the results of NH3-TPD after the resistance of SO2 (Fig. 2), it can be seen that the change of acid content of Cu-2Fe/T9 is minimal, which may be because it inhibits the adsorption of SO2 and generates less sulfate. The lireratures pointed out that inhibiting the adsorption of SO2 is one of the effective ways to solve SO2 poisoning [33–35]. And the most amazing thing is that the catalytic performance of 2Fe-Cu/T9 were deteriorating rather noticeably, it might be due to the presence of clusters and the formation of sulfates, blocking the pore of the molecular sieve. When SO2 is shut off, the NH3-SCR activities of Cu/T9 and Cu-2Fe/T9 remain basically unchanged for 2 h and the activity of 2Fe-Cu/T9 raises the monitor slightly, demonstrating the deactivation of 2Fe-Cu/T9 seems to be only partly reversible. When the reaction keep going for 10 h, H2O is introduced and the activity of Cu/T9 is unchanged. While Fe-T9, 2Fe-Cu/T9 and Cu-2Fe/T9 shows worse inferior catalytic activity than Cu/T9, it is because monomeric iron is more susceptible to water [36]. The study found that the migration of iron ions out of the ion-exchange sites was facilitated in the existence of H2O [37] and the migration of ion-exchanged iron aggregates to generate metal oxide clusters, leading to the decline of NOx activity [38]. To clarify the denitrification properties of mono-metal catalysts, DFT density functional theory is investigated [39]. Taking Cu/T9 catalyst as an example, a theoretical model was established (Fig. 3 ). The results of adsorption energy over Cu/T9 and Fe/T9 are shown in Table 1. Conclusions can be drawn from the results: 1. The adsorption of NH3 is exothermic and the adsorption of NO is endothermic. Therefore, NH3 is easily adsorbed at the active site, so it can be inferred that the strongly adsorbed NH3 directly interacts with gaseous or weakly adsorbed NO, that is, the NH3-SCR reaction on the catalyst surface mainly follows the E-R mechanism. 2. The adsorption SO2 is endothermic over Fe/T9 and Cu/T9 and the adsorption energy of SO2 over Fe/T9 is lower than that of Cu/T9. Therefore, SO2 is more easily adsorbed at the Fe site, however, according to the anti-sulfur activity (Fig. 1d), the effect of SO2 on the activity of Fe/T9 is lower than that of Cu/T9 at low temperatures, which may be because Fe/T9 is more prone to "fast SCR" reaction, and Cu/T9 is not prone to fast SCR reaction, but mainly to standard SCR reaction. Wijayanti et al. [40] found that the conversion of NOx during standard SCR showed a more pronounced decrease compared to that of fast SCR and the smallest effect of the sulfur poisoning was observed for SCR. 3. The absorption of NO is endothermic and the adsorption energy of NO over Fe/T9 is lower than that of Cu/T9. Therefore, it is easier to adsorb NO at the Fe site, resulting in NO oxidation reaction, which is consistent with the results of NO oxidation experiments (Fig. 1c) and the sulfur poisoning (Fig. 1d). 4. The adsorption of NH3 is exothermic and the heat release of Fe/T9 is much greater than that of Cu/T9. Therefore, it is easier to adsorb NH3 at the Fe site. Yu et al. [41] explored the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism and NH3 oxidation on Cu/SAPO-34 catalyst, and they found that the adsorbed NH3 was conducive to the NH3-SCR reaction. Consequently, it is theoretically possible that the catalytic activity of Fe/T9 is better than Cu/T9 in the reaction temperature window. However, the catalytic activity of Fe/T9 is worse than Cu/T9 at the low temperature, which is because Fe3+ is easily reduced to Fe2+ in excess NH3 below 300 °C [17]. 5. The adsorption of H2O is exothermic and the heat release of Fe/T9 is much greater than that of Cu/T9. Therefore, it is easier to adsorb H2O at the Fe site. Therefore, Fe is more susceptible to the attack of H2O, which is consistent with the result of the resistance of H2O (Fig. 1e). 3.2 Structural and morphology characterizations The XRD patterns of the prepared catalysts are displayed in Fig. 4 , which shows that each sample has the characteristic TNU-9 diffraction peaks [7]. In comparison to Na-T9, the diffraction peaks of Cu/T9, Fe/T9, 1Fe-Cu/T9, 2Fe-Cu/T9 3Fe-Cu/T9, Cu-2Fe/T9 and Cu2Fe/T9 have not altered substantially, which signifies that the structure of the support is apparently undamaged in the preparation process. In addition, no diffraction peaks of metal and metal oxides are found in the supported catalyst, indicating that the active components Cu and Fe particles were small and dispersed uniformly. Fig. 5 displays the SEM images of the synthesized catalysts. From Fig. 5a, the support TNU-9 has a cubic block crystal structure [7,42]. The morphology of Cu/T9, Fe/T9 and Cu-2Fe/T9 catalysts is the same as that of TNU-9, and the surface is smooth. The 2Fe-Cu/T9 catalyst shows a cubic block crystal structure as a whole, but the surface is rough and the crystal aggregation degree is higher, which may be because Fe2+ oxidizes to form oxide clusters [43]. The SEM-mapping of the two typical catalysts 2Fe-Cu/T9 and Cu-2Fe/T9 is shown in Fig. 6 . It can be seen that Fe and Cu are successfully introduced to the support, which is consistent with the results of ICP test (Table S1). The dispersion of active components Fe and Cu is more uniform for the Cu-2Fe/T9 catalyst. 3.3 Surface acidity and redox behavior The acidic site is conducive to the adsorption and activation of ammonia during the reaction, which is conducive to the improvement of SCR activity [44–47]. To explore the acid site on the catalyst surface, Pyridine-IR test (Fig. S1) and NH3-TPD test are conducted (Fig. 7 ). From Fig. S1, the infrared bands observed at ca. 1448 and 1545 cm−1 of all catalysts can be attributed to pyridine adsorption associated with Lewis and Bronsted acid sites, respectively [48]. It is apparent from Fig. 7a that the peak near 170 °C (peak 1) belongs to the attachment NH3 of weak Lewis acid at Al site outside the skeleton [20,25], the peak near 220 °C (peak 2) is attributed to the strong Lewis acid site of Fe and Cu exchange [25,49], and the peak near 360 °C (peak 3) is attributed to the enhanced chemical adsorption of ammonia at the strong Brønsted acid site (Si-OH+-Al) [20,25,50]. It has been reported that Brønsted acid could retain NH3, which was conducive to SCR reaction [48,51]. The acid content results after fitting are listed in Table 2 . It can be seen that Cu-2Fe/T9 has more Brønsted acid content than 2Fe-Cu/T9, which is one of the reasons for its better SCR activity. It is conclude from Fig. 7b that the peak position is changed and the acid content of the catalyst increases after the resistance of SO2, which may be due to the formation of sulfate and the generation of more acidic sites [29,30]. Fig. 8 shows the H2-TPR profiles of samples. The peak of Fe/T9 that centered at 369 °C is ascribed to Fe3+→Fe2+, as well as the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. [19,25,52]. The reduction peak of Cu-2Fe/T9 appeared at 351 °C and 481 °C belong to the reduction of Fe3+→Fe2+, Fe2O3→Fe3O4 and Cu2+→Cu+→Cu0. The reduction peaks shifted to the lower temperature for the Cu-Fe/T9, indicating that the redox of Cu-2Fe/T9 is better than 2Fe-Cu/T9 and Cu2Fe/T9 [53]. It is consistent with the results of catalytic performance, indicating that redox ability is conducive to SCR reaction and is an important factor affecting NH3-SCR activity. 3.4 The surface composition It is crucial that the valence and the percentage content of elements for SCR activity, which are determined by XPS. The XPS spectra of Cu 2p, Fe 2p, and O 1s of all catalysts are shown in Fig. 9 . As shown in Fig. 9A, the Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2 peaks of all catalysts can be deconvoluted into two peaks, respectively. The two peaks at 934.0 and 954.3 eV are due to Cu2+, and two peaks centered at 932.6 and 952.9 eV belong to Cu+ [54,55]. In addition, there is a small satellite peak at 943.3 eV, indicating the presence of Cu2+ in the catalyst. In the Fe 2p spectrum (Fig. 9B), there are two characteristic peaks of Fe 2p3/2 (711.0 eV) and Fe 2p2/1 (724.0 eV). In the XPS spectral deconvolution results of Fe 2p, 710.5 eV and 722.5 eV belong to the peaks of Fe2+, 711.8 eV and 726.0 eV belong to the peaks of Fe3+ [25,50]. In addition, near 716 eV and 729 eV belong to satellite peaks. The peaks centered at ca. 532 eV and 531.4 eV are attributed to the surface adsorbed oxygen (Oα) and lattice oxygen (Oβ), respectively (Fig. 9C). The percentages of element valences based on deconvolution peak areas are shown in Table 3 We can see that 2Fe-Cu/T9 and Cu-2Fe/T9 have more Cu2+ and Fe3+ than Cu/T9 and Fe/T9, indicating that the interaction of Cu and Fe can increase the proportion of active ions and thus increase the SCR activity. It is reported that isolated Fe3+and Cu2+ were the main active species at Fe-based catalyst and Cu-based catalyst, respectively [25,56]. Both Cu2+/(Cu2++Cu+) and Fe3+/(Fe3++Fe2+) of Cu-2Fe/T9 are higher than those of 2Fe-Cu/T9 and Cu2Fe/T9, indicating that the metal exchange order affects the proportion of active centers. Oα is conducive to the oxidation of NO to NO2, resulting in "fast SCR" and improving the denitrification performance [57]. Among all catalysts, Cu-2Fe/T9 has the highest Oα/(Oα+Oβ) content, which is consistent with the results of NH3-SCR. 4 Conclusions It is concluded that the reason for the inhibition of NH3 on Fe/T9 is not the competitive adsorption of NH3 and NO, but perhaps because, Fe3+ is easily converted to Fe2+ below 300 °C in the presence of excess NH3, resulting in poor low-temperature activity of Fe/T9. According to DFT theoretical calculation, SO2 is more easily adsorbed at the Fe site, and activity test shows that SO2 has a greater effect on Cu/T9 in the low temperature region, but a smaller effect on Fe/T9. This may be because Fe/T9 is prone to “fast SCR”, which slows down the toxic effect of SO2. SO2 has a positive effect on both Cu/T9 and Fe/T9 under high temperature. According to TPD results, it is speculated that more strong acid sites are produced due to the sulfate, leading to increasing catalytic activity. Water resistance experiments show that Cu/T9 has better water resistance than Fe/T9. In addition, Cu and Fe co-supported catalysts show a wider temperature window than mono-metal catalysts due to the synergistic effect between metals, and the optimal loading of Fe is 2 %. Cu-2Fe/T9 has wider temperature window than 2Fe-Cu/T9 and Cu2Fe/T9. In addition, the first exchange of Cu can minimize the oxidation of Fe3+. And interestingly enough, Cu-2Fe/T9 has better the resistance of H2O and SO2. coredata.dc:description: Enlarging reaction temperature and raising the resistance of SO2 and H2O for NH3-SCR is still a challenge. Meanwhile, the role of Fe and Cu over the supported TNU-9 catalysts is not so clear either for NH3-SCR reaction. Aiming at the above-mentioned problems, Fe and Cu bimetallic co-doped TNU-9 catalysts were prepared by solution ion-exchanged method and the effect of the exchanged order of Fe and Cu on NH3-SCR activity was conducted. What's more, the resistance of SO2/H2O and DFT calculations are also investigated. As a comparison, the activity Fe/T9 and Cu/T9 were examined. The reason that the different activity of Fe and Cu was also explained through DFT calculations. The glorious catalyst, Cu-2Fe/T9 synthesized via exchanging Cu first for twice and then Fe for once, demonstrated outstanding catalytic performance with the NOx conversion ca. 100 % at 225–450 °C and exceeding 80 % in the temperature range of 200–500 °C. It was attributed to minimizing the oxidation of Fe2+. And the most amazing thing was that Cu-2Fe/T9 had better the resistance of SO2 and worse the resistance of H2O than Cu/T9 at 225 °C. It was because that SO2 was more easily adsorbed at the Fe site, resulting in Fe protecting the active site Cu and the sulfation also provided more strong acidic sites, which were confirmed by DFT calculations and NH3-TPD. In addition, monomeric iron was more susceptible to water and the migration of ion-exchanged iron aggregated to form metal oxide clusters.
